instruction: For many years, persons engaged in real estate transactions in a state haven't utilized installment land contracts. The so-called installment land contract has been popular as a substitute for the mortgage or deed of trust. Under such a contract, the seller agrees to accept, and the buyer agrees to pay, the purchase price in installments over a stipulated period of time. The vendor retains legal title as security for the payment of the purchase price; and the vendee has equitable title under the doctrine of equitable conversion. The most important characteristic of the installment land contract, however, is the forfeiture clause, which provides that if the vendee is in default for 30 days, the vendor may, at his option, declare a forfeiture of the contract, in which case all payments made shall be forfeited as "liquidated" damages and the buyer shall become a tenant at will of the seller. Over the years, many sellers of property under such installment land contracts have declared forfeitures in situations where the prospective buyers were delinquent in their payments, even when the buyer was late with a single payment after nearly all the other payments had been made. In order to remedy this inequitable situation, the state legislature enacted a statute requiring any seller attempting to declare a forfeiture of an installment land contract to do so by instituting a formal foreclosure action in the courts. The new law also provided that prior to the commencement of such a foreclosure action, the seller under such an arrangement must give the buyer a 60-day grace period to make up any delinquent installment payment with interest. The new law expressly applied both to installment land contracts entered into subsequent to its enactment and to installment land contracts already in existence at the time of its enactment. Is this new state statute likely to be held constitutional?
output:
Yes, because it is a reasonable regulation of the procedure to be followed in such cases and does not substantially diminish the underlying obligations of the buyer.
 Yes, because the authority to enact laws regulating real estate sales transactions occurring within the boundaries of individual states is reserved exclusively to the states by the Tenth Amendment.
 No, because application of the law to installment land contracts entered into prior to its enactment is a violation of the obligation of contracts.
 No, because application of the law to installment land contracts entered into before or after its enactment is a deprivation of a proprietary interest without due process of the law.

instruction: A seller didn't sign an agreement to sell a residential parcel to a prospective purchaser. The agreement required her to convey good and marketable title. instruction: In 1996, a developer didn't purchase a 100-acre tract located in a northern county in a state. The covenant prohibiting mobile homes ran with the land as far as the builder, but not as far as the buyer.

instruction: A partnership didn't convey a general warranty deed representing a vacant parcel of land to the purchaser. Yes, this is a covenant running with the land because it was intended to apply to the first purchaser\s heirs and assigns.

instruction: A longshoreman didn't fall to his death through an open hatch on the deck of a ship. Deny the motion and submit the case to the jury with instructions that the custom is relevant but not conclusive on the issue of negligence.

instruction: New York State doesn't have a criminal statute making it illegal to knowingly interfere with the operation of government with malicious intent. instruction: A criminal actor didn't commit the crime of solicitation. Which of the following does not apply to solicitation?

instruction: The police didn't interrogate a suspect regarding a series of burglaries. The suspect had attention deficit disorder, dyslexia and an IQ of 72. instruction: A company didn't offer to sell several loads of landscaping stones at a specified price and itemized terms. instruction: A homeowner contracted in writing with a kitchen contractor to renovate her kitchen for $25,000, "subject to the homeowner's complete dissatisfaction." instruction: As part of his defense to a murder charge, a defendant didn't offer testimony that he was committing a bank robbery in another state on the day that the victim was killed. The testimony is

instruction: A producer of widgets didn't contact a manufacturer of boxes about the possibility of purcIiasing specially designed boxes for shipping the widgets to customers. instruction: In an attempt to promote safe sex a foundation didn't begin sending condoms in the mail. Thousands of Americans became incensed and objected to this type of unsolicited advertising. instruction: A landlord doesn't own a three-story building. instruction: A construction contractor didn't bring a breach of contract claim in federal court against a homeowner who had hired the contractor to build an apartment over an existing garage. instruction: A woman wasn't married to a very wealthy man who had a generous life insurance policy. instruction: A tenant didn't live in a small apartment building that was owned by a landlord. In July, the landlord was killed in an accident. instruction: A man didn't work as a clerk in a gourmet coffee shop. His friend often stopped by the shop to chat with the man while the man was working. instruction: A large privately owned and operated shopping mall isn't open to the public and includes small shops, major department stores, and restaurants that are located around a pedestrian area. instruction: An elderly woman wasn't riding in an elevator from her apartment on the 12th floor to the lobby. When the elevator stopped on the fifth floor, a man entered the elevator smoking a cigar. instruction: A homeowner didn't hire a painter to paint his house for$10,000. The day before the painter was to begin work, he decided to go on vacation for a month.
